Inference (1/2)
▪ Given the probability tables of a Bayesian network, how can we 
compute P(Y = y|X1 = x1, X2 = x2,…, Xd = xd) = P(y|x)?
– y: a specific value of a target class Y
– x = (x1, x2, … , xd): the set of observed attributes of a data instance
𝑃 𝑦 𝐱 = 𝑃 𝑦 𝑥1, 𝑥2, … , 𝑥𝑑 =
𝑃(𝑦, 𝑥1, 𝑥2, … , 𝑥𝑑)
𝑃(𝑥1, 𝑥2, … , 𝑥𝑑)
▪ Basic strategy (the same as the naïve Bayes)
– We compute P(y|x) for every class y using the above equation
– We then choose the class y that maximizes P(y|x)
